articles.headline: In Greece’s Crisis, Fed Studies Wall St.’s Activities
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is examining the stratagems devised by Goldman Sachs and other big banks to help Greece mask its burgeoning debt over the last decade.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is examining the stratagems devised by Goldman Sachs and other big banks to help Greece mask its burgeoning debt over the last decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Greece’s problems deepened on both sides of the Atlantic as the Federal Reserve disclosed it was investigating Goldman Sachs and other banks that helped the country mask its debts, and investors grew increasingly leery of lending any more money to a nation flirting with default.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Sewell Chan

articles.headline: Mayor’s Housing Offer Sets Off Row in Jerusalem
articles.snippet: Disagreements have arisen over matters of ownership and the demographics of East Jerusalem.
articles.abstract: Disagreements have arisen over matters of ownership and the demographics of East Jerusalem.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The mayor of Jerusalem is offering 120 Palestinian families in a jumble of houses scheduled for demolition a deal he believes they can’t refuse: new apartments atop shops and restaurants, a day care center, boutique hotels and a huge park. Tourists and income will flow. It is — as the mayor likes to say — win-win.

articles.headline: On Wall Street, a Romance With Curling
articles.snippet: The oddball of the Olympics has captivated traders thanks to CNBC, which covers curling after the closing bell.
articles.abstract: The oddball of the Olympics has captivated traders thanks to CNBC, which covers curling after the closing bell.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wall Street trading is often described as a blood sport. But inside the great investment houses, the sport of the moment is, of all things, curling  that oddball of the Olympics that is sort of like shuffleboard on ice.

articles.headline: In Tax Law, an Overdue Overhaul a Step, With Miles to Go
articles.snippet: Senators are cooperating on a bipartisan effort to overhaul the tax code as the need to pass a new bill grows more urgent.
articles.abstract: Senators are cooperating on a bipartisan effort to overhaul the tax code as the need to pass a new bill grows more urgent.
articles.lead_paragraph: What is the most outrageous section of American tax law?

articles.headline: Radiation Bills Raise Question of Supervision
articles.snippet: Officials are investigating billing practices at a Florida cancer center, a case that points up oversight concerns.
articles.abstract: Officials are investigating billing practices at a Florida cancer center, a case that points up oversight concerns.
articles.lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Fla. — To help ensure that medical radiation is safe, Medicare insists that certain highly technical cancer treatments be administered only when a patient’s radiation oncologist is present or nearby.
articles.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Rebecca R. Ruiz

articles.headline: Clearing the Air at American Ports
articles.snippet: The Teamsters’ Union and environmental activists are allies in a push for the short-haul trucking companies working in ports to buy new, low-emission rigs.
articles.abstract: The Teamsters’ Union and environmental activists are allies in a push for the short-haul trucking companies working in ports to buy new, low-emission rigs.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Teamsters union and environmental activists have formed an unlikely and outspoken alliance aiming to clear the air in American ports, and perhaps bolster the Teamsters’ ranks in the process.

articles.headline: Traction for Banking Regulation
articles.snippet: Banking representatives and the Treasury secretary say that they have agreed on the need to get a bill through Congress this year.
articles.abstract: Banking representatives and the Treasury secretary say that they have agreed on the need to get a bill through Congress this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The prospect of a financial regulatory overhaul’s passing Congress brightened on Thursday, as representatives of the banking industry left a meeting with the Treasury secretary saying that they had agreed on the need to get a bill through Congress this year.

articles.headline: Plan to Seek Use of U.S. Contracts as a Wage Lever
articles.snippet: The White House plans to use the government’s buying power to prod private companies to improve wages.
articles.abstract: The White House plans to use the government’s buying power to prod private companies to improve wages.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration is planning to use the government’s enormous buying power to prod private companies to improve wages and benefits for millions of workers, according to White House officials and several interest groups briefed on the plan.

articles.headline: A.I.G. Posts Loss of $11 Billion on Higher Claims
articles.snippet: The insurance giant attributed most of its $11 billion loss for the year to a fourth-quarter charge taken to reflect that its bailout had been restructured.
articles.abstract: The insurance giant attributed most of its $11 billion loss for the year to a fourth-quarter charge taken to reflect that its bailout had been restructured.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American International Group said on Friday that it lost about $11 billion last year, surprising analysts and showing the long-term risks inherent in the types of large, complex insurance coverage that the company once pioneered.
